discussion.author: CohenCyril
discussion.comment: The canonical way to refer to `nat_scope` in mathcomp is `%N`.

discussion.author: proux01
proux01
discussion.comment: Rebased, all overlays merged, this will be mergeable whenever we decide to drop support for Coq 8.11 and 8.12.

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment: I don't understand this, the scope is supposed to be determined by `AC` (and`%AC`) (and all the numbers are actually `positive` I think)

review_discussion.author: proux01
review_discussion.comment: There is no notation for 2, 3 or 4 in AC_scope and none of the AC notations is opening neither positive nor nat scope, so the most recently opened scope with such a notation is used.

review_discussion.author: proux01
review_discussion.comment:
What we could though is to add a number notation in AC_scope that reads numbers as positive.
That should even be a one liner, I'll try that.

commits.author: proux01
commits.message: Add a number notation in AC_scope

commits.author: proux01
commits.message:
Add %N for natural numbers

This is done in preparation to the addition of a number notation in
scope ring_scope. So we want to avoid natural number constants such as
2 or 3 to be interpreted in ring_scope.

commits.author: proux01
commits.message:
Add a number notation for ring

Now, 12 or 42 are read as 12%:R or 42%:R in scope ring_scope.
If ssrint is imported, -6 is read as (-6)%:~R.

One may have to add a few %N in code that was using concrete
nat values in scope ring_scope.

commits.author: proux01
commits.message:
Remove useless %:R on numbers

2 is now a notation for 2%:R
